title: Reflection of Light
subject: integrated-science
description: Investigate the law of reflection and understand how light bounces off different surfaces
objectives: Measure angles of incidence and reflection
Verify that angle of incidence equals angle of reflection
Identify the normal line in reflection diagrams

theory.introduction: Reflection is the bouncing back of light when it hits a surface. This phenomenon is responsible for our ability to see objects and is the principle behind mirrors and many optical devices.
keyPoints: The incident ray is the light approaching the surface
The reflected ray is the light bouncing off the surface
The normal is an imaginary line perpendicular to the surface at the point of incidence
The angle of incidence (i) is measured between the incident ray and the normal
The angle of reflection (r) is measured between the reflected ray and the normal

lawOfReflection.statement: The angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection (∠i = ∠r)
conditions: The incident ray, reflected ray, and normal all lie in the same plane
Both angles are measured from the normal, not from the surface

procedure.instruction: Place a plane mirror on a white sheet of paper
procedure.safety: Handle the mirror carefully to avoid cuts

procedure.instruction: Draw a line at the base of the mirror - this represents the reflecting surface
procedure.note: Keep the mirror perpendicular to the paper

procedure.instruction: Draw a normal (perpendicular line) at the center of the mirror line
procedure.tip: Use a protractor to ensure the normal is exactly 90° to the surface

procedure.instruction: Direct a light ray toward the mirror at an angle (e.g., 30°) from the normal
procedure.warning: Do not shine laser pointers into eyes

procedure.instruction: Mark the path of the incident ray and the reflected ray
procedure.note: Use a ruler for straight lines

procedure.instruction: Measure the angle of incidence using a protractor
procedure.tip: Measure from the normal, not from the mirror surface

procedure.expected: Should equal the angle of incidence

procedure.purpose: Verify the law holds for all angles

expected: For every incident angle, the reflected angle is equal
Light always reflects symmetrically about the normal
The rays and normal line are coplanar
The relationship holds for any smooth reflecting surface

applications.description: Used in homes for grooming and decoration. Create virtual images that appear behind the mirror.
Use two plane mirrors at 45° to allow users to see over obstacles or around corners.
Use multiple mirrors at angles to create beautiful symmetric patterns through multiple reflections.
Reflecting telescopes use curved mirrors to gather and focus light from distant objects.
Arrays of mirrors reflect and concentrate sunlight onto solar collectors for energy generation.
Rearview and side mirrors use reflection to help drivers see behind and beside their vehicles.

safety: Never shine bright lights or lasers directly into eyes
Handle glass mirrors carefully to avoid cuts from sharp edges
Use only low-power laser pointers (Class 2 or below)
Secure mirrors to prevent them from falling
Clean glass surfaces carefully to avoid slipping
Work in a well-lit room to reduce eye strain

quiz.question: According to the law of reflection, the angle of incidence is:
options: Equal to the angle of reflection
Greater than the angle of reflection
Less than the angle of reflection

quiz.question: Angles of incidence and reflection are measured from:
Which type of surface gives the clearest reflection?
What is the normal line in reflection?
options: A line perpendicular to the surface at the point of incidence

extendedLearning.diffuseReflection: Rough surfaces scatter light in many directions (diffuse reflection), while smooth surfaces produce clear images (specular reflection).
extendedLearning.totalInternalReflection: When light travels from a denser medium to a less dense medium at angles greater than the critical angle, it reflects completely back into the denser medium. This principle is used in fiber optics.
extendedLearning.curvedMirrors: Concave mirrors can focus light to a point, while convex mirrors spread light out. Both still follow the law of reflection at each point on the surface.

vocabulary.definition: The bouncing back of light when it strikes a surface
The ray of light approaching the reflecting surface
The ray of light bouncing off the reflecting surface
An imaginary line perpendicular to the surface at the point of incidence
The angle between the incident ray and the normal
The angle between the reflected ray and the normal
